intro: Alkanna maleolens, commonly known as the red sandalwood or red dye plant, is a member of the Malvaceae family. It is native to regions of North America, particularly the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. The plant is characterized by its distinctive red, fleshy roots that contain a red dye used historically by indigenous peoples. Its flowers are typically yellow or orange, with five petals and stamens, and it produces capsule fruits containing numerous seeds. The plant thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often growing in rocky soils and along dry streambeds.
